doc.title: Issues for debate post 2Q25
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-28/Hapag-Lloyd Issues for debate post 2Q25Hapag-Lloyd Issues for debate post 2Q25_2025-08-28

passages.text: Key issues include: 3Q/FY25 volume + rate outlook, Tariffs and trade developments, Inventory levels, Demand/supply dynamics, Trade lane dynamics, Impact of Gemini on cost and pricing, Cost savings program, Capacity discipline vs. replenishing fleet.
What's the debate? In this report, we summarise key issues for investors to discuss with Hapag- Lloyd management following the company's 2Q25 results on August 14th, 2025.

Top of the agenda: Potential upside to 3Q on extension, but HLAG still expects a slowdown in 2H, which begs the question: how weak can 4Q be? After recent news around an extension of the US- China 90- day pause, management saw bookings pick up on the China to US trade lane. We see this as another moving part to a very volatile year, which may provide some upside to volumes and potentially rates in 3Q. However, it remains to be seen how long this mini- pick up can last, as we also question where inventory levels in the US sit following the early peak in May/June. Management commented that it expects front- loading and higher permanent tariffs could slow down demand in 2H25, and we remain cautious on how 2H25 volumes will develop if a weaker US consumer and destocking trends start to materialise. We also continue to view the mid- term oversupply issue in the industry as unavoidable, as there is no historical evidence of the industry being disciplined with scrapping capacity, and, assuming the Red Sea reopens, the demand/supply balance should return back to 4Q23 levels – which points to low rates and risky profitability for the industry.

View and valuation. We reiterate our Underweight rating, with a PT of €92. Our PT equates to EV/EBITDA multiples of 5x and 7x on our 2025/26 forecasts, respectively, slightly below the stock's historical average multiple of 7.5x. The stock is currently trading at 7x EV/EBITDA in FY25e and 10x in FY26e, with the latter significantly above its historical average. Although the new Gemini network should support a more robust volume outlook, given greater network efficiency boosts asset utilisation, we continue to see downside risk to FY26/27 Bloomberg consensus, while FY26 will depend on timing of Red Sea re- opening and geopolitical variables. We look for signs of industry structural repair to emerge to turn more constructive on the overall sector, focusing on scrapping picking up as charters roll off in 2025, the orderbook being consistently depleted and idling increasing.
For our post 2Q25 report see, ZIM/HLAG: 2H and 2026 still risky - UW.
This research report has been prepared in whole or in part by equity research analysts based outside the US who are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 6. Completed: 27- Aug- 25, 19:01 GMT Released: 28- Aug- 25, 04:09 GMT Restricted - External
European Transportation
Potential Upside/Downside Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
European Transportation

Current trading. Management commented on 3Q rates up QoQ vs. 2Q and 3Q25 EBITDA at least in line with 2Q, commenting that the underlying performance and rates should be better in 3Q vs. 2Q, given rate strength at end of 2Q, but that the company benefited from favourable oneoffs in 2Q that will not repeat in 3Q. Can management discuss and quantify these one- offs? What is the view on rates for 3Q and why? Management expects volume growth to moderate vs. \(12\%\) in 2Q - what kind of growth is expected in 3Q and 4Q?

Risks from tariffs. Hapag- Lloyd grew volumes \(12\%\) yoy in 2Q vs. co- cons \(+6\%\) (Maersk 2Q volumes \(+4\%\) YoY). According to management, growth was particularly strong on the Pacific and Asia- Europe trade routes, and reflected HLAG's sustained investment in fleet capacity and the successful transition to the new Gemini East- West network. Following the recent extension of the US- China 90- day pause, management noted that bookings from China to US were stronger in the first few days, but it remains to be seen how much of a mini- rush this will be. How long is this stronger demand expected to last? With 1Q and 2Q volume still strong, how high are US inventories? How does vessel capacity allocation differ today vs. pre- tariffs? Has most of the capacity that shifted away from the CH- US trade returned?

FY25 outlook narrowed. Management narrowed its outlook for FY25 EBITDA to €2.5- 3.4bn, vs. €2.4- 3.9bn previously (FY24A €4.6bn). During the 2Q25 conference call, management commented that the outlook has been narrowed in light of the solid performance in H1, but that risks remain elevated. Front- loading and higher permanent tariffs may also drive a slowdown in demand in 2H25. Can management elaborate on what this means for its previously communicated \(>10\%\) volume ambition? What does management expect in 3Q in terms of rates/ volumes vs. 2Q? What was the vessel utilisation in FY24, and what is management expecting for FY25? Why is Hapag- Lloyd's volume ambition greater than Maersk's, despite both using the same network? How are FY25 volumes expected to develop across trade lanes given recent developments? Does the Gemini network have a competitive advantage amid tariffs? Hapag has lower exposure to Transpacific, higher to Transatlantic. How easily can Hapag move capacity to other trade lanes?

Cost reduction program ongoing. At 1Q Hapag- Lloyd initiated a cost reduction program with an objective to remove \(>USD\) 1bn of costs over 18 months by the end of FY26 (vs. opex of \(\) 17bn) through fleet productivity, asset utilisation and SG&A levers. HLAG still targets a \(20\%\) cost reduction vs. the 2022 Covid peak by 2030, but this would equate to \(10\%\) above pre- Covid cost levels. Management expects to start to see impacts of the cost saving program come through gradually in 2H. Approximately \(50\%\) of this cost savings target will come from synergy and efficiency gains from the Gemini cooperation. When should we expect to see the full runrate of Gemini- related savings? Has the Gemini transition incurred more costs than expected in 1H? What are the main initiatives underpinning the program? Is it dependent on a macro recovery? How will new vessel deliveries contribute to unit cost reductions? How much incremental cost does management expect in terms of EU ETS costs alone for FY25? Will Hapag- Lloyd be able to recover these as well as any FuelEU costs?

Gemini cooperation. During the 2Q conference call, management commented that the phase- in is largely concluded, and it expects to see some cost benefits come through gradually in 3Q and 4Q. At 2Q, costs included a triple- digit million USD headwind from Gemini transition costs. How much more implementation cost should we expect? Management commented that costs were a bigger headwind for HLAG than for Maersk as the changes to its network were more drastic than they were for Maersk. Can management elaborate on why? Is Gemini a driver of cost savings and better asset utilisation or a driver of volumes and pricing? Is reliability a differentiating factor, with a lot of container cargo being low- value items? Can management

discuss why Maersk is a better partner to team up with than Hapag- Lloyd's old alliance (ONE, HMM and Yang Ming)? What are the hub- and- spoke model bring? What makes HLAG and Maersk confident about defining on quality, which is crucial in a hub- and- spoke model amid global supply chain issues? How can they control quality and insulate against external factors? Is a hub- and- spoke model faster than point- to- point?

Littl evidence of scrapping being able to solve oversupply, in our view. Management remains unworried by the new wave of orders as an issue, given the ageing global fleet as well as the environmental regulations that are being introduced, which will require carriers to sail slower in future. Management still expects significant scrapping even between now and the end of FY27, as there is an increasing number of ships \(>25\) years. When should we see scrapping start to pick up? How much scrapping capacity is there p.a.? Does the recently implemented Hong Kong convention reduce scrapping capacity? How long is the waiting list for scrapping and do shipping lines have to plan in advance? Pre 3Q24, HLAG announced the order of 24 LNG vessels planned for delivery in 2027- 29, of which \(12 \times 16.8k\) TEU will be used to expand capacity, and another \(12 \times 9.2k\) TEU vessels are planned to replace capacity. Are there any plans to scrap older vessels before the 12 new ones are delivered? How can the industry avoid oversupply putting further pressure on freight rates? Is management concerned that industry structural repair will now be delayed and the oversupply situation may actually worsen in the event of a sudden Red Sea resolution? When the Red Sea re- opens, how much capacity can be absorbed by slow steaming? Is environmental regulation homogeneous enough across regions to drive harmonised behaviour? Can shippers demanding green transportation drive scrapping?

Spot and contract rates. During the 4Q24 conference call, management commented that the share of long- term business has increased by a MSD- HSD \(0 / 0\) , which was a conscious choice to position the company to achieve its \(>10\%\) volume ambition. The move also provides some protection against spot rate fluctuations; however, HLAG commented that it is still vulnerable if spot rates fall too much. Can management elaborate on the trends seen in the Transpacific contract negotiations (HLAG is \(70 / 30\%\) contract/spot on Transpacific) in terms of shippers' willingness to sign contracts earlier or later, and what are the main areas of contention during these discussions? Is there a minimum contract rate from management's perspective, and, if so, has this changed, given the greater focus on maintaining a higher share of contracts in the portfolio? Can management talk about the mix of contracts by duration? How sensitive are contracts to movements in spot rates via surcharges? How enforceable are contract rates should spot rates start to correct rapidly?

Capacity discipline relative to market share in Liner business. According to Alphaliner, Hapag- Lloyd has maintained its top five position in terms of market share over the past three years. As mentioned below, maintaining a top five position is part of Hapag- Lloyd's strategy. How does management expect to achieve this? What risks come with this approach? Does scale matter in the container shipping industry? Should we expect a continuation of new vessel orders in FY25? What is the primary driver of new orders - regulation or scale? How will the Terminals business contribute to retaining a top five position? Could it impede Hapag- Lloyd's progress towards achieving its 'Pure Play Plus' strategy? What will the impact be if it loses out on scale to competitors?

Strategy 2030. Hapag- Lloyd outlined its strategy 2030 roadmap at its CMD earlier this year. The roadmap includes continued investments to transform into 'Pure Play Plus' by growing its terminal portfolio and its inland share, continuing to achieve a top five position among global container lines, reaching an on- time delivery rate of \(>80\%\) by 2030 (now c. \(50\%\) ), reducing GHG emissions by a third by 2030 and remaining an industry frontrunner in operations and digitalisation. Management outlined at the CMD that, in executing on Strategy 2030, it will require growth investments of c. \(20 - 25bn\) and deliver incremental EBIT of \(>52bn\) by 2030. What

proportion of EBIT will the Terminals business generate by 2030, and what is the strategy behind Terminals' growth? What trends is management currently seeing regarding the uptake of Terminals and Infrastructure products by Liner shipping customers? Can Hapag- Lloyd offer a competitive product offering compared with the global freight forwarders? Will the customer mix change post the collaboration with Maersk, which favours going direct with large Beneficial Cargo Owners? What does asset control bring to its customers? What about its hub- and- spoke initiative under the Gemini cooperation?

Sustainability efforts. Management flagged that its Ship Green product, launched in 2023, has seen quite good uptake in the market, doubling TEUs sold in FY24 vs. FY23, and seeing significant YoY growth again in FY25. How has Hapag- Lloyd been able to successfully charge customers a premium fee for more sustainable supply chain/transportation products? Will environmental requirements reduce effective capacity? If so, how will the competitive landscape adjust in response, and how fast does Hapag- Lloyd believe this could happen? Have recent market dynamics accelerated or hindered Hapag- Lloyd's commitment to net zero by 2040? Hapag- Lloyd's IMO ambition changed recently and is now to achieve net zero by 2050. What is Hapag- Lloyd's view on what is needed to successfully decarbonise shipping and is the introduction of a market- based mechanism essential to achieve this? Management expects environmental costs to double in FY25 vs. FY24 as the scope of the EU ETS increases from 40% to 70%, and FuelEU begins in FY25. What is the expected cost in FY26 when the EU emissions trading scheme covers 100% of relevant emissions?
Relevant recent research that covers some of the issues highlighted: 2Q25 preview: volumes ok, rates/yields down QoQ. 2H macro risk remains, published 27 June, 2025.
Global Container Shipping: Environmental regulation not costly enough to offset oversupply – confirm UW ratings, published 21 January, 2025.

Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.
Below is the list of companies that constitute the "industry coverage universe":

Valuation Methodology: We value Hapag- Lloyd based on the relationship between ROIC and EV/IC. Our price target of €92 is based on a 0.92x multiple applied to our Invested Capital estimate in 2025 as we anticipate negative EBIT in 2026, with negative ROIC vs a cost of capital of €7%.

Risks which May impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: More effective capacity management measures improving the supply- demand imbalance. Successful execution of Hapag- Lloyd's terminal and infrastructure acquisitions. Lower unit cost through successful cost reduction programs. Lower bunker fuel costs. Active or passive impact of industry consolidation.

Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
*This is the closing price referenced in the publication, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.
Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.

**Valuation** **Methodology:** We value ZIM on a 0.7x EV/IC applied to our average 2025E/26e IC to reflect our view of significant oversupply risk in 2025 and 2026 assuming the Red Sea disruption eases.

**Risks** **which** **May** **Impede** **the** **Achievement** **of** **the** **Barclays** **Research** **Valuation** **and** **Price** **Target:** ZIM has high operating leverage ($100 on rates impacts 2024E EBITDA by $360mn, all else equal). Stronger than expected global economic growth and hence trade volume growth, stronger than expected freight rates due to capacity-demand balance and bunker oil price movements that are recovered through freight rates are upside risks to our price target. Downside risks include ZIM's expansion strategy potentially diluting earnings, the new vessel leasing plan potentially increasing operational and financial leverage, systems failure leading to increased costs and/or indeed a geopolitical event disrupting operations.

Sustalable nvesting Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.

Any information, data, image, or other content including from a third party source contained, referred to herein or used for whatsoever purpose by Barclays or a third party ("Information"), in relation to any actual or potential 'ESG', 'sustainable' or equivalent objective, issue, factor or consideration is not intended to be relied upon for ESG or sustainability classification, regulatory regime or industry initiative purposes ("ESG Regimes"), unless otherwise stated. Nothing in these materials, including any images included therein, is intended to convey, suggest or indicate that Barclays considers or represents any product, service, person or body mentioned in these materials as meeting or qualifying for any ESG or sustainability classification, label or similar standards that may exist under ESG Regimes. Barclays has not conducted any assessment of compliance with ESG Regimes. Parties are reminded to make their own assessments for these purposes.
